mentions.context: BEETL and RopeBWT use explicit separator characters but such characters could be replaced by bitvectors marking positions at the ends of reads.

BEETL and RopeBWT use a heuristic to reduce the number of runs in the EBWT: they conceptually put the separator characters at the ends of reads into the co-lexicographic order (lexicographic order on the reverse string, also referred to as reverse lexicographic order) of the reads, so that the final characters or reads with similar suffixes are grouped together in 13:3 the EBWT.
BEETL and RopeBWT use explicit separator characters but such characters could be replaced by bitvectors marking positions at the ends of reads.

BEETL and RopeBWT use a heuristic to reduce the number of runs in the EBWT: they conceptually put the separator characters at the ends of reads into the co-lexicographic order (lexicographic order on the reverse string, also referred to as reverse lexicographic order) of the reads, so that the final characters or reads with similar suffixes are grouped together in 13:3 the EBWT.
The first index for readsets based on the EBWT was BEETL [15], followed by RopeBWT [40]; recently the EBWT has been used also by the Spring compressor [11] specialized for FASTQ reads.
The reference used is the longest contig assembled by MSRCA v1.8.3 [59] as it was the most accurate assembler according to the Gage-b companion paper [44].

As a heuristic for reducing the number of runs, and thus reducing BEETL's space usage, Cox et al. suggested considering the lexicographic order of the copies of $ to be the strings' co-lexicographic order.
The first index for readsets based on the EBWT was BEETL [15], followed by RopeBWT [40]; recently the EBWT has been used also by the Spring compressor [11] specialized for FASTQ reads.
The same construction was also used in subsequent indexes for readsets, such as RopeBWT [40] and Spring [11].

Its most important application so far has been in standard short-read aligners -Bowtie [39,38] and BWA [41] have together over 70 thousand citations and are used every day in clinics and research labs worldwide -but it has myriad other uses and more are still being discovered.
The same construction was also used in subsequent indexes for readsets, such as RopeBWT [40] and Spring [11].

Its most important application so far has been in standard short-read aligners -Bowtie [39,38] and BWA [41] have together over 70 thousand citations and are used every day in clinics and research labs worldwide -but it has myriad other uses and more are still being discovered.
The first index for readsets based on the EBWT was BEETL [15], followed by RopeBWT [40]; recently the EBWT has been used also by the Spring compressor [11] specialized for FASTQ reads.

Just within computational genomics, FM-indexes have been generalized from single strings to collections of strings for tools such as BEETL [15], RopeBWT [40] and Spring [11], to de Bruijn graphs for tools such as BOSS [8], VARI [48] and Rainbowfish [2], and to graphs for tools such as vg [27].

Since our XBWT implementation does not use the $ symbol, for a fair comparison we measured the number of runs with and without the $ for EBWT, Spring+EBWT and RLO+EBWT (therefore ignoring for all algorithms the extra cost of implicitly encoding the ending position of each string).

Just within computational genomics, FM-indexes have been generalized from single strings to collections of strings for tools such as BEETL [15], RopeBWT [40] and Spring [11], to de Bruijn graphs for tools such as BOSS [8], VARI [48] and Rainbowfish [2], and to graphs for tools such as vg [27].

The FM-index is an important data structure in combinatorial pattern matching and bioinformatics, and is itself the basis for popular tools such as Bowtie [39,38] and BWA [41] that align DNA reads to reference genomes.

Just within computational genomics, FM-indexes have been generalized from single strings to collections of strings for tools such as BEETL [15], RopeBWT [40] and Spring [11], to de Bruijn graphs for tools such as BOSS [8], VARI [48] and Rainbowfish [2], and to graphs for tools such as vg [27].

The FM-index is an important data structure in combinatorial pattern matching and bioinformatics, and is itself the basis for popular tools such as Bowtie [39,38] and BWA [41] that align DNA reads to reference genomes.

We computed all EBWT variants using ropeBWT2 [40]; in addition to plain EBWT we also tested 2 heuristics that reorder the reads to reduce the number of runs in the EBWT: Spring [11] and reverse lexicographic order (RLO) [14], the latter obtained using the option -s in ropeBWT2.

The FM-index plays a central role here too: Mantaci et al. [47] generalized the BWT to the Extended BWT (EBWT), which applies to collections of strings, and then Cox et al. [5,13,30] used an FM-index built on the EBWT in their index BEETL for readsets.
